ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Assessment type:
Notes: 1 = Baseline; 2 = Post MCI; 3 = Week 4; 4 = Week 8; 5 = Week 12

ElementDescription: Was form completed?
Notes: 1 = Yes; 2 = No

ElementDescription: Considering your total clincal experience with this particular population, how mentally ill is the patient at this time?
Notes: 0 = Not assessed; 1 = Normal, not ill at all; 2 = Borderline mentally ill; 3 = Mildly ill; 4 = Moderately ill; 5 = Markedly ill; 6 = Severely ill; 7 = Among the most extremely ill patients; 88 = Not assessed

ElementDescription: Rate total improvement, regardless of whether or not in your opinion it is due entirely to treatment. Compared to his condition at admission to the project, how much has he changed?
Notes: 0 = Not assessed; 1 = Very much improved; 2 = Much improved; 3 = Minimally improved; 4 = No change; 5 = Minimally worse; 6 = Much worse; 7 = Very much worse; 88 = Not assessed

ElementDescription: Does the patient have Social Anxiety?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Does the patient have another illness?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Specify the other diagnosis of the illness
Rating of the other illness.
Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

ElementDescription: Does the patient have another illness?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Specify the other diagnosis of the illness

Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid.

ElementDescription: Does the patient have another illness?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Specify the other diagnosis of the illness

Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

ElementDescription: Does the patient have none of these illnesses?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Type of Major Depressive Disorder
Notes: 0 = Single; 1 = Recurrent

ElementDescription: Rating of Major Depressive Disorder
Notes: 0 = Mild; 1 = Moderate; 2 = Severe, with no psychotic features; 3 = Severe, with psychotic features; 4 = In full remission; 5 = In partial remission

ElementDescription: Age of onset of Major Depressive Disorder
Age of onset of current episode of Major Depressive Disorder
Age when most recent episode, before the current Major Depressive Disorder episode, ended.
Type of persistent depressive disorder
Notes: 0 = With pure dysthymia; 1 = With persistent MDE; 2 = With intermittent MDE and current episode; 3 = With intermittent MDE without current episode

ElementDescription: Rating of Persistent Depressive Disorder
Notes: 0 = Mild; 1 = Moderate; 2 = Severe without psychotic features; 3 = Severe with mood-congruent psychotic features; 4 = Severe with mood-incongruent psychotic features;  5 = In full remission;  6 = In partial remission; 7 = Possible; 8 = Probable

ElementDescription: Age of onset of Persistent Depressive Disorder
Age of onset of current episode of Persistent Depressive Disorder
Does the patient have Major Depressive Disorder?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Age most recent episode before the current one of Persistent Depressive Disorder, ended.
Type of Bipolar Disorder
Notes: 0 = Bipolar I; 1 = Bipolar II

ElementDescription: Type of current-recurrent for Bipolar Disorder
Notes: 0 = Depressed; 1 = Manic; 2 = Mixed

ElementDescription: Rating of Bipolar Disorder
Notes: 0 = Mild; 1 = Moderate; 2 = Severe, with no psychotic features; 3 = Severe, with psychotic features; 4 = In partial remission; 5 = In full remission; 6 = Possible; 7 = Probable

ElementDescription: Type of ADHD
Notes: 0 = Inattentive; 1 = Hyperactivity/Impulsive;  2 = Combine

ElementDescription: Rating of ADHD
Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

ElementDescription: Type of Disruptive Behavior Disorder
Notes: 0 = ODD; 1 = NOS; 2 = CD

ElementDescription: Rating of Disruptive Behavior Disorder
Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

ElementDescription: Rating of Generalized Anxiety Disorder
Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

ElementDescription: Rating of Social Anxiety
Notes: 0 = Possible; 1 = Probable; 2 = In remission; 3 = In partial remission; 4 = Mild; 5 = Moderate; 6 = Severe; 7 = Comorbid

Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Considering your total clinical experience with this particular population, how mentally ill is the patient at this time?
Notes: 1 = Normal - Not at all ill; 2 = Borderline mentally ill; 3 = Mildly ill; 4 = Moderately ill; 5 = Markedly ill; 6 = Severely ill; 7 = Among the most extremely ill patients

ElementDescription: Rate of total improvement, compared to the patient's condition at the start of the study, how much has he/she changed?
Notes: 1 = Very much improved; 2 = Much improved; 3 = Minimally improved; 4 = No change; 5 = Minimally worse; 6 = Much worse; 7 = Very much worse

ElementDescription: Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been THE THIRD WEEK OF OBSERVATION (3rd week since O0)?
Notes: 0 = Already done at O2; 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been THE FOURTH WEEK OF OBSERVATION (4th week since O0)?
Notes: 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: EXTRA - If it has been more than 4 weeks since the start of OBSERVATION, obtain CGI rating for the previous week. Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been over THE PAST WEEK? (most recent week)
Notes: 0 = Not done; 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been OVER THE PAST WEEK?
Notes: 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been OVER THE PREVIOUS WEEK (ie., 2 weeks ago)?
Notes: 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: Visit type
Notes: 1 = in person; 2 = phone

ElementDescription: Site
Notes: Study Site

ElementDescription: Visit name
CGI Observation Week #1 (first week after O0). Considering your total clinical experience with bipolar patients, how severely ill has the patient been OVER THE FIRST WEEK of observation?
Notes: 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

Notes: 0 = Already done at O2; 1 = NORMAL, NOT AT ALL - Symptoms of disorder not present past seven days; 2 = MINIMALLY ILL - Subtle or suspected pathology; 3 = MILDLY ILL - Clearly established symptoms with minimal, if any, distress or difficulty in social and occupational function; 4 = MODERATELY ILL - Overt symptoms causing noticeable, but modest, functional impairment or distress; symptom level may warrant medication; 5 = MARKEDLY ILL - Intrusive symptoms that distinctly impair social/occupational function or cause intrusive levels of distress; 6 = SEVERELY ILL - Disruptive pathology; behavior and function are frequently influenced by symptoms; may require assistance from others; 7 = VERY SEVERELY ILL - Pathology drastically interferes in many life functions; may be hospitalized

ElementDescription: Please consider, for a moment, your total experience with child, focusing on the child''s main problems. Consider such factors as whether his/her problems affect his/her homework, school work, and relationships. Also consider how severe a problem this is.
Notes: 1=Normal, no impairment; 2=Slight Impairment; 3=Mild Impairment; 4=Moderate Impairment; 5 = Severe Impairment; 6 = Very Severe Impairment; 7 = Maximal, profound impairment

ElementDescription: Which of the following describes your child''s overall progress since being in the program?
Notes: 1 = Much worse; 2 = Moderately worse; 3 = Slightly worse; 4 = About the same; 5 = Slightly improved; 6 = Moderately improved; 7 = Much improved
